In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can define a function to wrap text by splitting the input string into words and then rejoining them with newlines when the length of the current line exceeds a specified width. Here's how you can implement such a function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    # Split the text into words, but don't include whitespace at the end of each line
    lines = split(text, r"\s+", keepempty=false)
    
    # Initialize an empty string to which we will add wrapped lines
    wrapped_text = ""
    
    # Iterate over the words and build the wrapped text
    for word in lines
        if length(word) + length(wrapped_text) > text_width
            # If the current line is too long, start a new line
            wrapped_text *= "\n"
        end
        
        # Append the word to the wrapped text
        wrapped_text *= word * " "
    end
    
    return wrapped_text[1:end-1] # Remove the trailing space
end
```

This function takes an `AbstractString` as input and wraps it at a specified width. It does this by splitting the text into words, then appending each word to a new line if the current line length exceeds the specified width. The function also handles the case where the last word in the string is too long for a single line by trimming the trailing space from the wrapped text.

Here's an example of how you can use this function:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there! This is a very long sentence that I would like to wrap at 10 characters per line.")
"Hello there!\nThis is a very\nlong sentence\nthat I would\nlike to wrap\nat 10 characters\nper line."
```

In this example, the text is wrapped at 10 characters per line, and the newlines are inserted after each word that would cause the line length to exceed this limit.
